3 REASONS I‚ÄôM BULLISH ON $TSLA ENTERING 2026

1. Robotaxis finally shift from ‚Äúcan it work‚Äù to ‚Äúdoes the math work‚Äù
In 2026, Tesla starts proving whether autonomy is economically superior to human drivers. If Tesla can run a robotaxi cheaper than $UBER or $GOOGL Waymo on a fully loaded basis then the debate moves away from sensor philosophies and toward margins. Cost wins markets.

2. Tesla‚Äôs data flywheel moat becomes visible
Tesla runs a closed loop where millions of vehicles generate real-world data and that data retrains the system and improvements are pushed back out via software. By 2026, the advantage shows up in how fast performance improves MoM. Autonomy becomes a learning rate problem and Tesla‚Äôs system learns faster.

3. Energy storage becomes required infrastructure
AI data centers drive uneven power demand, renewables add volatility and utilities need storage to stabilize the system. Tesla sells exactly that so as AI power consumption rises then energy scales alongside it creating a second growth engine independent of vehicle cycles.

$ASML is projecting ~$55B in revenue by 2030 with gross margins approaching 60%.

That only works because every advanced chip built by $TSM and designed by $NVDA still has to pass through ASML‚Äôs tools.

ASML remains the AI kingmaker.

IS $NVDA REALLY IN TROUBLE IN 2026?

When people talk about custom silicon replacing Nvidia they tend to focus almost entirely on the chip itself which is the wrong place to focus. Designing a chip is hard but it is not the hardest part of running large-scale AI systems since the real difficulty begins after the chip exists when you still have to move massive amounts of data between chips, keep them synchronized, schedule workloads efficiently and maintain a software stack that developers can actually use without rewriting everything from scratch.

That is why the argument that ASICs will make Nvidia irrelevant in 2026 is absolutely absurd. Yes, hyperscalers like $GOOGL and $AMZN will continue to build their own chips and in some narrow, well-defined workloads those chips will perform very well. What most people underestimate is how difficult it is to build and sustain the networking layer, optical interconnects, memory hierarchy and developer tooling required to run reliable AI clusters at scale. Those systems take years to mature and they never stop evolving. Google‚Äôs TPU stack is a good example having taken multiple generations before becoming a broadly viable alternative even within Google‚Äôs own ecosystem.

Nvidia‚Äôs advantage is that it already owns this complexity end to end since it ships a complete system that includes networking, software, tooling, and a roadmap that advances every year. That cadence matters more than most people realize since internal chip teams typically move in multi-year cycles and by the time a custom system is fully deployed at scale, Nvidia is already shipping the next generation and resetting the performance baseline. The result is a persistent gap where internal teams are optimizing for yesterday‚Äôs constraints while Nvidia is solving tomorrow‚Äôs problems.

There will be cases where custom silicon makes sense over the long term, particularly for stable, repeatable workloads but for most companies the outcome is not replacement. It is coexistence since internal chips will be used where they fit best and Nvidia will be used everywhere else because it offers a full ecosystem that developers already know, trust and can deploy without operational risk. From a practical standpoint, that is usually the lowest-risk and most cost-effective choice.

Nvidia will be the world's first $10T company.
